channel.title: Watir WebDriver
channel.description: the most elegant way to use webdriver with ruby

item.title: Watir WebDriver
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
Welcome to the home of Watir WebDriver: the most elegant way to use WebDriver with ruby. Watir (pronounced Water: I know it's confusing) stands for Web Application Testing in Ruby, and the WebDriver part stands for, um, WebDriver.

What browsers does Watir-WebDriver support?

Any browser that WebDriver supports: namely Firefox, Chrome & IE. Safari support is sadly gladly missing now available.

How good is Watir-WebDriver?

I could make up lots of quotes about how good it is, but I don't need to, it's that good.

Getting Started

gem install watir-webdriver
or just add watir-webdriver to your gemfile if you rock and use bundler (if you don't use bundler, you should, right now). Watir-WebDriver ♥s ruby 1.9.3, but it won't complain in older versions nonetheless

Getting Going

Ready, steady... at a prompt, type irb. Meet Ruby, your servant who will perform any (syntactically correct) command you can throw her way. So type in the following commands one by one (but don't shout them) to see some amazing things happen in browserland: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.new b.goto 'bit.ly/watir-webdriver-demo' b.text_field(:id => 'entry_0').set 'your name' b.select_list(:id => 'entry_1').select 'Ruby' b.select_list(:id => 'entry_1').selected? 'Ruby' b.button(:name => 'submit').click b.text.include? 'Thank you' [/sourcecode] Wow, wasn't that easy! You're a pro; you should make yourself a cup-of-tea for your good work.

Look Ma! No xpath selectors!

One of things you should have noticed straight away is the absense of xpath selectors. Whilst Watir-WebDriver fully supports xpath (and css) selectors, you'll find the API so awesome that you'll find you don't ever need to use them, unless you're feeling kinda messed up.

Look Ma! No training wheels test recorders

Automated test script recorders (like Selenium IDE) are for dummies. Seriously. The combination of the instant feedbackness of irb, with the awesomeness of the Watir-WebDriver API means you'll be way more productive and efficient using these two things that you'll ever be with a silly recorder. Plus your scripts will run 1000x better because you they won't be full of the guff that was recorded by that silly recorder, such as a 100 character css selector that neither you, or anyone else, understands.

♥ Cucumber and Watir-WebDriver sitting in a tree ♥

Cucumber + Watir-WebDriver are a match made in heaven. They work really well together to automate your web app testing with a business domain specific specification layer. See specification by example: a love story.

The power of ruby

Ruby is an amazing language and a joy to use. You'll often find something new each day that makes your life, and your love of ruby, that little bit better. Watir-WebDriver is no different.

item.title: Cookies
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
There is a cookie API in Watir-WebDriver 0.5.2 onwards, that is easy to use.
[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' browser = Watir::Browser.new browser.cookies.clear browser.cookies.add 'foo', 'bar', :path => "/", :expires => 10.days.from_now, :secure => true browser.cookies.delete 'foo' browser.cookies.to_a [/sourcecode]

item.title: Web Elements
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
All HTML elements are supported by Watir-WebDriver. Some examples are below:

Text Fields

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.start 'bit.ly/watir-webdriver-demo' t = b.text_field :id => 'entry_0' t.exists? t.set 'your name' t.value [/sourcecode]

Select Lists - Combos

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.start 'bit.ly/watir-webdriver-demo' s = b.select_list :id => 'entry_1' s.select 'Ruby' s.selected_options [/sourcecode]

Radios

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.start 'bit.ly/watir-webdriver-demo' r = b.label(:text => 'What is ruby?').parent.radio :value => 'A gem' r.exists? r.set r.set? [/sourcecode]

Checkboxes

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.start 'bit.ly/watir-webdriver-demo' c = b.label(:text => 'What versions of ruby?').parent.checkbox :value => '1.9.2' c.exists? c.set c.set? [/sourcecode]

Buttons

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.start 'bit.ly/watir-webdriver-demo' btn = b.button :value => 'Submit' btn.exists? btn.click [/sourcecode]

Links

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.start 'bit.ly/watir-webdriver-demo' l = b.link :text => 'Google Docs' l.exists? l.click [/sourcecode]

Divs & Spans

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"]require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.start 'bit.ly/watir-webdriver-demo' d = b.div :class => 'ss-form-desc ss-no-ignore-whitespace' d.exists? d.text s = b.span :class => 'ss-powered-by' s.exists? s.text [/sourcecode]

WYSIWYG Editors

See: WYSIWYG Editors page

item.title: Screenshots
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: Watir-WebDriver has a pretty awesome screenshot capability, built right in. [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] # Save screenshot to file browser.screenshot.save 'screenshot.png' # Represent screenshot as PNG image string browser.screenshot.png # Represent screenshot as Base64 encoded string browser.screenshot.base64 [/sourcecode] The great thing about this is it gives you a screen shot of the entire page, not just above the fold. If you're using Cucumber also, you can easily embed this in your html report output by adding the following to your env.rb file: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] After do |scenario| browser.screenshot.save 'screenshot.png' embed 'screenshot.png', 'image/png' end [/sourcecode]

item.title: Determining which Browser
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
You may want to determine which browser you are running in your Watir-WebDriver code.
It's simple to do:
[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome browser.driver.browser #=> :chrome [/sourcecode]

item.title: Browsers
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
Watir-WebDriver supports the browsers that WebDriver supports.

Firefox

Firefox is supported through a JavaScript driver, therefore 'it just works™' on all platforms. 
b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox

Chrome

Chrome support is through the platform specific ChromeDriver binary, which you download and put on your path. 
b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome

Internet Explorer

Internet Explorer should just work, as long as the protected mode setting is the same for every internet zone (all on, or all off). 
b = Watir::Browser.new :ie

item.title: Waiting
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
Waiting is usually problematic when you have dynamic web interfaces, eg. web sites that have lots of AJAX.

Explicit waits

There are four built in methods that you can use to make your waiting experience more pleasant (and remove those evil sleep statements from your code)
  • Watir::Wait.until { ... }: where you can wait for a block to be true
  • object.when_present.set: where you can do something when it’s present
  • object.wait_until_present:; where you just wait until something is present
  • object.wait_while_present:; where you just wait until something disappears
The default timeout for all these methods is 30 seconds, but your can pass an argument to any of these to increase (or decrease) it as needed. [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.start 'bit.ly/watir-webdriver-demo' b.select_list(:id => 'entry_1').wait_until_present b.text_field(:id => 'entry_0').when_present.set 'your name' b.button(:value => 'Submit').click b.button(:value => 'Submit').wait_while_present Watir::Wait.until { b.text.include? 'Thank you' } [/sourcecode]

Implicit waits

As an alternative, you can use the WebDriver's implicit waits to specify a maximum time (in seconds) the script will try to find an element before timing out. This is done by setting the property of the underlying driver: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.new b.driver.manage.timeouts.implicit_wait = 3 #3 seconds [/sourcecode] Note that using implicit waits can make your tests slower and more difficult to understand when they fail.

item.title: JavaScript Dialogs
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
JavaScript dialogs are fairly common in web applications. Watir-WebDriver has an inbuilt library for handling the dialogs, and capturing values from the dialogs.

JavaScript Alerts

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] # Check if alert is shown browser.alert.exists? # Get text of alert browser.alert.text # Close alert browser.alert.ok browser.alert.close [/sourcecode]

JavaScript Confirms

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] # Accept confirm browser.alert.ok # Cancel confirm browser.alert.close [/sourcecode]

JavaScript Prompt

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] # Enter text to prompt browser.alert.set "Prompt answer" # Accept prompt browser.alert.ok # Cancel prompt browser.alert.close [/sourcecode]

Alternative Method

If you're having trouble using the above method, you can override the JavaScript functions to return the value you want, so when they're meant to show, they don't! [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] # don't return anything for alert browser.execute_script("window.alert = function() {}") # return some string for prompt to simulate user entering it browser.execute_script("window.prompt = function() {return 'my name'}") # return null for prompt to simulate clicking Cancel browser.execute_script("window.prompt = function() {return null}") # return true for confirm to simulate clicking OK browser.execute_script("window.confirm = function() {return true}") # return false for confirm to simulate clicking Cancel browser.execute_script("window.confirm = function() {return false}") # don't return anything for leave page popup browser.execute_script("window.onbeforeunload = null") [/sourcecode]

item.title: Browser Popups
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: When a new browser window is opened, you can then 'use' the new window. [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] browser.window(:title => "annoying popup").use do browser.button(:id => "close").click end [/sourcecode] See the Window Switching Spec for more examples.

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: Welcome to the home of Watir WebDriver: the most elegant way to use WebDriver with ruby. Watir (pronounced Water: I know it’s confusing) stands for Web Application Testing in Ruby, and the WebDriver part stands for, um, WebDriver. What browsers does Watir-WebDriver support? Any browser that WebDriver supports: namely Firefox, Chrome & IE. Safari support is sadly missing. How good is Watir-WebDriver? I could make up lots of quotes about how good it is, but I don’t need to, it’s that good. Getting Started gem install watir-webdriver or just add watir-webdriver to your gemfile if you rock and use bundler (if you don’t use bundler, you should, right now). Watir-WebDriver ♥s ruby 1.9.2, but it won’t complain in older versions nonetheless Getting Going Ready, steady… at a prompt, type irb. Meet Ruby, your servant who will perform any (syntactically correct) command you can throw her way. So type in the following commands one by one (but don’t shout them) to see some amazing things happen in browserland: require ‘watir-webdriver’ b = Watir::Browser.new b.goto ‘bit.ly/watir-webdriver-demo’ b.text_field(:id => ‘entry_0′).set ‘your name’ b.select_list(:id => ‘entry_1′).select ‘Ruby’ b.select_list(:id => ‘entry_1′).selected? ‘Ruby’ b.button(:value => ‘Submit’).click b.text.include? ‘Thank you’ Wow, wasn’t that easy! You’re a pro;…

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: When a new browser window is opened

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: JavaScript dialogs are fairly common in web applications. The best way to automate these is to override the JavaScript functions to return the value you want, so when they’re meant to show, they don’t! [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] # don’t return anything for alert browser.execute_script(“window.alert = function() {}”) # return some string for prompt to simulate user entering it browser.execute_script(“window.prompt = function() {return ‘my name’}”) # return null for prompt to simulate clicking Cancel browser.execute_script(“window.prompt = function() {return null}”) # return true for confirm to simulate clicking OK browser.execute_script(“window.confirm = function() {return true}”) # return false for confirm to simulate clicking Cancel browser.execute_script(“window.confirm = function() {return false}”) [/sourcecode]

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: Watir-WebDriver has a pretty awesome screenshot capability, built right in. browser.driver.save_screenshot ‘screenshot.png’ The great thing about this is it gives you a screen shot of the entire page, not just above the fold.

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: There are four built in methods that you can use to make your waiting experience more pleasant (and remove those evil sleep statements from your code) Watir::Wait.until { … }: where you can wait for a block to be true object.when_present.set: where you can do something when it’s present object.wait_until_present:; where you just wait until something is present object.wait_while_present:; where you just wait until something disappears The default timeout for all these methods is 30 seconds, but your can pass an argument to any of these to increase (or decrease) it as needed.

item.title: Page Objects
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
The Page Object pattern is a way to represent pages and their elements in reusable classes. The watir-webdriver wiki has a thorough explanation of the concept. There are several gems that help you implement page objects:
  • Watir Page Helper
  • LoadableComponent

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: Representing your app in page classes

item.title: Elements
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: Text Fields Select Lists – Combos Checkboxes & Radios Buttons & Links Divs & Spans WYSIWYG Editors There are two ways to enter text into a WYSIWYG editor using Watir-WebDriver: locate the iFrame, and use .send_keys to enter text execute javascript on the browser object that sets the value of the WYSIWYG editor CKEditor [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require ‘watir-webdriver’ b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox b.goto ‘http://ckeditor.com/demo’ b.execute_script(“CKEDITOR.instances['editor1'].setData(‘hello world’);”) b.frame(:title => ‘Rich text editor, editor1, press ALT 0 for help.’).send_keys ‘hello world again’ [/sourcecode] TinyMCE Editor [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require ‘watir-webdriver’ b = Watir::Browser.new b.goto ‘http://tinymce.moxiecode.com/tryit/full.php’ b.execute_script(“tinyMCE.get(‘content’).execCommand(‘mceSetContent’,false, ‘hello world’ );”) b.frame(:id => “content_ifr”).send_keys ‘hello world again’ [/sourcecode]

item.title: WYSIWYG Editors
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
There are two ways to enter text into a WYSIWYG editor using Watir-WebDriver:

  • locate the iFrame, and use .send_keys to enter text (downside is browser must be in the foreground)
  • execute javascript on the browser object that sets the value of the WYSIWYG editor (most reliable method)
CKEditor [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox b.goto 'http://ckeditor.com/demo' b.execute_script("CKEDITOR.instances['editor1'].setData('hello world');") b.frame(:title => 'Rich text editor, editor1, press ALT 0 for help.').send_keys 'hello world again' [/sourcecode] TinyMCE Editor [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.new b.goto 'http://tinymce.moxiecode.com/tryit/full.php' b.execute_script("tinyMCE.get('content').execCommand('mceSetContent',false, 'hello world' );") b.frame(:id => "content_ifr").send_keys 'hello world again' [/sourcecode]

item.title: Browser Downloads
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
The easiest and best way of dealing with file downloads is to avoid the pesky file download dialogs altogether. This is done by programatically telling the browser to automatically save files to a certain directory, that your test can access.

Firefox

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] download_directory = "#{Dir.pwd}/downloads" download_directory.gsub!("/", "\\") if Selenium::WebDriver::Platform.windows? profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile['browser.download.folderList'] = 2 # custom location profile['browser.download.dir'] = download_directory profile['browser.helperApps.neverAsk.saveToDisk'] = "text/csv,application/pdf" b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox, :profile => profile [/sourcecode] A full list of these Firefox options are available in firefox by typing 'about:config' in the address bar. If you want to know a way to work out the file types (eg. application/pdf) then you can read the following blog post for an step by step guide.

Chrome

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] download_directory = "#{Dir.pwd}/downloads" download_directory.gsub!("/", "\\") if Selenium::WebDriver::Platform.windows? profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Chrome::Profile.new profile['download.prompt_for_download'] = false profile['download.default_directory'] = download_directory b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :profile => profile [/sourcecode] See a full list of Chrome preferences

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: The easiest and best way of dealing with file downloads is to avoid the file download boxes altogether. This is done by programatically telling the browser to automatically save files to a certain directory, that your test can access. Firefox profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile['browser.download.folderList'] = 2 #custom location profile['browser.download.dir'] = “#{Dir.pwd}/downloads” profile['browser.helperApps.neverAsk.saveToDisk'] = “text/csv,application/pdf” b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox, :profile => profile A full list of these Firefox options are available in firefox by typing ‘about:config‘ in the address bar. Chrome profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Chrome::Profile.new profile['download.prompt_for_download'] = false profile['download.default_directory'] = “#{Dir.pwd}/downloads” b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :profile => profile See a full list of Chrome preferences

item.title: Browser Proxies
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
Example: setting a http and https proxy for Firefox

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile.proxy = Selenium::WebDriver::Proxy.new :http => 'my.proxy.com:8080', :ssl => 'my.proxy.com:8080' browser = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :profile => profile [/sourcecode]

Example: setting a http and https proxy for Chrome

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] switches = '--proxy-server=my.proxy.com:8080' browser = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :switches => switches [/sourcecode]

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: Example: setting a http and https proxy for Firefox profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile.proxy = Selenium::WebDriver::Proxy.new :http => ‘my.proxy.com’, :ssl => ‘my.proxy.com’ browser = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :profile => profile Example: setting a http and https proxy for Chrome switches = ‘–proxy-server=my.proxy.com’ browser = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :switches => switches

item.title: Measure Page Performance
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
The Watir-WebDriver-Performance gem aims to provide a set of navigation timing metrics for Watir-WebDriver actions using a W3C page performance standard. This is a perfect solution to capture response time metrics, and it's very straightforward to do but currently only works in Chrome and IE9l, so there's no Firefox support. [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' require 'watir-webdriver-performance' b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome 10.times do b.goto 'http://watir.com' load_secs = b.performance.summary[:response_time]/1000 puts "Load Time: #{load_secs} seconds." end [/sourcecode] This produces something like: 
Load Time: 3.701 seconds.
Load Time: 0.694 seconds.
Load Time: 1.874 seconds.
Load Time: 1.721 seconds.
Load Time: 2.096 seconds.
Load Time: 0.823 seconds.
Load Time: 2.362 seconds.
Load Time: 1.008 seconds.
Load Time: 1.761 seconds.
Load Time: 2.066 seconds.
List of available metric groupings
  • :summary
  • :navigation
  • :memory
  • :timing

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: The Watir-WebDriver-Performance gem aims to provide a set of navigation timing metrics for Watir-WebDriver actions. This is a perfect solution to capture response time metrics, and it’s very straightforward to do but only currently works in Chrome and IE9 at the moment – no Firefox support. require ‘watir-webdriver’ require ‘watir-webdriver-performance’ b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome 10.times do b.goto ‘http://watir.com’ puts “Load Time: #{b.performance.summary[:response_time]/1000} seconds.” end This produces something like: Load Time: 3.701 seconds. Load Time: 0.694 seconds. Load Time: 1.874 seconds. Load Time: 1.721 seconds. Load Time: 2.096 seconds. Load Time: 0.823 seconds. Load Time: 2.362 seconds. Load Time: 1.008 seconds. Load Time: 1.761 seconds. Load Time: 2.066 seconds. List of available metric groupings :summary :navigation :memory :timing Summary

item.title: Firefox
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
It just works™

Firefox is supported through a JavaScript driver, therefore 'it just works™' on all platforms. [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox [/sourcecode]

Firefox Profiles

By default, the Firefox driver creates a new Firefox profile for each test run, which is the recommended action. You can specify an existing profile to use, such as your 'default' profile: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"]b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox, :profile => 'default'[/sourcecode] You can also create a new Firefox profile each test run using any of the options that you can configure in the about:config pane of Firefox For example: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile['browser.download.dir'] = "/tmp/webdriver-downloads" profile['browser.download.folderList'] = 2 profile['browser.helperApps.neverAsk.saveToDisk'] = "application/pdf" b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox, :profile => profile [/sourcecode]

Native Events on Microsoft Windows

Native events are enabled on Windows by default and intend to provide a lower level interaction between webdriver and the operating system. However, these seem to cause problems in certain conditions. These can be easily disabled by setting the option on the Firefox profile: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile.native_events = false Watir::Browser.new :firefox, :profile => profile [/sourcecode]

Specifying a proxy to use with Firefox

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile.proxy = Selenium::WebDriver::Proxy.new :http => 'myproxy.com:8080:, :ssl => 'myproxy.com:8080' b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox, :profile => profile [/sourcecode]

Using Firebug with Watir-WebDriver

First download the Firebug xpi file, then use the following code: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile.add_extension "../path/to/firebug.xpi" b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox, :profile => profile [/sourcecode]

item.title: Chrome
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
ChromeDriver

Chrome support is through the platform specific ChromeDriver binary, which you download and put on your path. [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"]b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome[/sourcecode]

Chrome Profiles

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Chrome::Profile.new profile['download.prompt_for_download'] = false profile['download.default_directory'] = "/path/to/dir" b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :profile => profile [/sourcecode] See the full list of profile options here.

Chrome Switches

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :switches => %w[--ignore-certificate-errors --disable-popup-blocking --disable-translate] [/sourcecode] See the full list of switches here.

Using a proxy with Chrome

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :switches => %w[--proxy-server=myproxy.com:8080] [/sourcecode]

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: It just works™ Firefox is supported through a JavaScript driver, therefore ‘it just works™’ on all platforms. b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox Firefox Profiles By default, the Firefox driver creates a new Firefox profile for each test run, which is the recommended action. You can specify an existing profile to use, such as your ‘default’ profile: b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox, :profile => ‘default’ You can also create a new Firefox profile each test run using any of the options that you can configure in the about:config pane of Firefox For example: profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile['browser.download.dir'] = “/tmp/webdriver-downloads” profile['browser.download.folderList'] = 2 profile['browser.helperApps.neverAsk.saveToDisk'] = “application/pdf” b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox, :profile => profile Specifying a proxy to use with Firefox profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile.proxy = Selenium::WebDriver::Proxy.new :http => ‘myproxy.com:8080:, :ssl => ‘myproxy.com:8080′ b = Watir::Browser.new WEB_DRIVER, :profile => profile

item.title: Internet Explorer
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
IE on Windows

Internet Explorer is Windows only (duh!) and only works if you ensure that protected mode is either all on, or all off, for all zones. [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] b = Watir::Browser.new :ie [/sourcecode]

Internet Explorer Config

Watir-WebDriver uses your standard IE settings and config, so you should manually adjust IE to how you want it before running your tests, which will pick up these settings.

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: IE on Windows Internet Explorer is Windows only (duh!) and only works if you ensure that protected mode is either all on, or all off, for all zones. b = Watir::Browser.new :ie Internet Explorer Config Watir-WebDriver uses your standard IE settings and config, so you should manually adjust IE to how you want it before running your tests, which will pick up these settings.

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: ChromeDriver Chrome support is through the platform specific ChromeDriver binary, which you download and put on your path. b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome Chrome Profiles profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Chrome::Profile.new profile['download.prompt_for_download'] = false profile['download.default_directory'] = “/path/to/dir” b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :profile => profile See the full list of profile options here. Chrome Switches b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :switches => %w[--ignore-certificate-errors --disable-popup-blocking --disable-translate] See the full list of switches here. Using a proxy with Chrome b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :switches => %w[--proxy-server=myproxy.com:8080]

item.title: Sending Special Keys
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
To send special keys to an element or browser page, you use the .send_keys method, with a symbolic representation of what you would like to send. [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] b.send_keys :enter [/sourcecode] You can also do things like this: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] b.element.send_keys [:control, 'a'], :backspace [/sourcecode] You can also modify the click behaviour with keys: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] b.element.click(:shift, :control) [/sourcecode] The full list of keys are available from here:
  • :null
  • :cancel
  • :help
  • :backspace

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: To send special keys to an element or browser page, you use the .send_keys method, with a symbolic representation of what you would like to send. b.send_keys :enter You can also do things like this: b.element.send_keys [:control, 'a'], :backspace The full list of keys are available from here: :null :cancel :help :backspace :tab :clear :return :enter :shift :left_shift :control :left_control :alt :left_alt :pause :escape :space :page_up :page_down :end :home :left :arrow_left :up :arrow_up :right :arrow_right :down :arrow_down :insert :delete :semicolon :equals :numpad0 :numpad1 :numpad2 :numpad3 :numpad4 :numpad5 :numpad6 :numpad7 :numpad8 :numpad9 :multiply :add :separator :subtract :decimal :divide :f1 :f2 :f3 :f4 :f5 :f6 :f7 :f8 :f9 :f10 :f11 :f12 :meta :command

item.title: Mobile Devices
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
There are three options for using watir-webdriver to test mobile sites:
  • running tests against an embedded browser on a real device;
  • running tests against an embedded browser on a device emulator on a desktop machine; or
  • running tests against a desktop browser that is configured with the same resolution and user-agent credentials as a mobile browser.
Running against real and emulated devices (either iOS or Android) is both costly and is not as fast as using desktop browsers. There are documented details on setting up the iOS driver here and Android here. Using a real Apple device requires an Apple developer account which costs around $99. A much easier and more efficient way is to use a desktop browser configured to mimic that of a mobile browser. This is extremely easy to do with the webdriver-user-agent gem: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' require 'webdriver-user-agent' driver = UserAgent.driver(:browser => :chrome, :agent => :iphone, :orientation => :landscape) browser = Watir::Browser.new driver browser.goto 'tiffany.com' browser.url.should == 'http://m.tiffany.com/International.aspx' [/sourcecode] The gem currently supports firefox and chrome as desktop browsers, and iphone, ipad, android_phone, and android_tablet as devices; portrait and landscape orientations are also available.

item.title: Headless
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
The headless gem is a ruby wrapper for Xvfb that makes it super easy to run graphical applications (such as real web browsers) on a headless Linux machine. This gem is perfect for running headless Watir-WebDriver tests using a real browser.

An Example

[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' require 'headless' headless = Headless.new headless.start b = Watir::Browser.start 'www.google.com' puts b.title b.close headless.destroy [/sourcecode]

A Cucumber Example

You should add the following code to your env.rb file: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] if ENV['HEADLESS'] require 'headless' headless = Headless.new headless.start at_exit do headless.destroy end end [/sourcecode]

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: You may want to determine which browser you are running in your Watir-WebDriver code. It’s simple to do: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require ‘watir-webdriver’ b = Watir::Browser.new :chrome browser.driver.browser #=> :chrome [/sourcecode]

item.title: Browser Certificates
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
Firefox

The Firefox driver properly handles untrusted certificates by default. If you have a trusted certificate, but there is some other certificate error such as a hostname mismatch (eg. using a production certificate in test), you should do the following: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile.assume_untrusted_certificate_issuer = false b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox, :profile => profile [/sourcecode] The reason this is needed is explained here.

Chrome

It is easy to ignore invalid Browser certificates in Google Chrome by passing a command line switch: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :switches => ['--ignore-certificate-errors'] [/sourcecode]

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: If you’d like to ignore invalid Browser certificates, you can do so like this. Firefox [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] profile = Selenium::WebDriver::Firefox::Profile.new profile.assume_untrusted_certificate_issuer = false b = Watir::Browser.new :firefox, :profile => profile [/sourcecode] Chrome [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] Watir::Browser.new :chrome, :switches => ['--ignore-certificate-errors'] [/sourcecode]

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: This site is written by Alister Scott from Brisbane, Australia.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks for letting us know. We will update the page as soon as possible. If you would like to help, let us know.
webdriver-user-agent has been deprecated (v. 6.6.6). Should update the Browsers->Mobile page
http://watir.com/ has a lot of good content and links.

Hey Alister. Thank you for creating such a great tool! I've been working in Ruby for a while and enjoy the heck out of it. Are there any resources that you would recommend for diving deeper into Watir?
Hi, I read in some other articles that it ia possible to run watir to parallel process getting web pages. Can you point me to some example of how to implement this?
finding an element in a pop up is a challenge. I was able to create script to the end and finally struck. all the method used and no solution.
Mozilla will launch a new plataform just for devels, Watir does now work just right now with recent firefox versions...

Alister, I'm very grateful! Thank you! Over the last few months you've inspired me to change my workflow and overcome a big barrier to web testing.
Could you please share your insight on `Browser Downloads` for PhantomJS since it doesn't have a Selenium::WebDriver::PhantomJS::Profile? Cheers!

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: The headless gem is a ruby wrapper for Xvfb that makes it super easy to run graphical applications (such as real web browsers) on a headless Linux machine. This gem is perfect for running headless Watir-WebDriver tests using a real browser. An Example> [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require ‘watir-webdriver’ require ‘headless’ headless = Headless.new headless.start b = Watir::Browser.start ‘www.google.com’ puts b.title b.close headless.destroy [/sourcecode] A Cucumber Example You should add the following code to your env.rb file: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] if ENV['HEADLESS'] require ‘headless’ headless = Headless.new headless.start at_exit do headless.destroy end end [/sourcecode]

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: The headless gem is a ruby wrapper for Xvfb that makes it super easy to run graphical applications (such as real web browsers) on a headless Linux machine. This gem is perfect for running headless Watir-WebDriver tests using a real browser. An Example> [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require ‘watir-webdriver’ require ‘headless’ headless = Headless.new headless.start b = Watir::Browser.start ‘www.google.com’ puts b.title b.close headless.destroy [/sourcecode] A Cucumber Example You should add the following code to your env.rb file: [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] if ENV['HEADLESS'] require ‘headless’ headless = Headless.new headless.start at_exit do headless.destroy end end [/sourcecode]

item.title: Basic Browser Authentication
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: The easiest and most elegant way to handle basic browser authentication is to supply the username and password in the URL, bypassing the dialog altogether. [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.start 'http://admin:password@yourwebsite.com' [/sourcecode] Proxy Authentication If the above method doesn't work, eg. you are authenticating against a NTLM proxy, you may have find using the AutoAuth Firefox extension will enable you to automatically dismiss this dialog with your credentials. See this blog post for full details. Example Basic Browser Authentication Dialog

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: The easiest and most elegant way to handle basic browser authentication is to supply the username and password in the URL, bypassing the dialog altogether. [sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] require ‘watir-webdriver’ b = Watir::Browser.start ‘http://admin:password@yourwebsite.com’ [/sourcecode] Example Basic Browser Authentication Dialog

item.title: Frames
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
Frames are fairly easy to deal with in Watir-WebDriver, just use them the same way as any other element.
[sourcecode language="ruby" light="true"] b.frame(:id => "content_ifr").send_keys "hello world" [/sourcecode]

item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded: This site is written by Alister Scott from Brisbane, Australia.

item.title: Safari
item.dc:creator: bpettichord
item.content:encoded:
Watir-WebDriver supports Safari thanks to the release of SafariDriver. The downside is the set up is quite lengthy at the moment as it requires a Safari extension (version 5+) and until someone publishes the extension to the online gallery, you'll have to build it yourself. Steps to build the extension
  1. First, create and install a Safari extension certificate at Apple. You'll need to sign up for a (free) Safari developer account, and download your certificate locally.
  2. Now, you'll need to build the extension. First, you'll need to check out the selenium source code to do so: 
    svn co http://selenium.googlecode.com/svn/trunk selenium
  3. Then change into this directory and build the extension 
    cd selenium
./go safari
  4. Finally, install your extension:
    1. Launch Safari
    2. Ensure develop menu is shown by setting it in Advanced Preferences 
    3. Open the Extension Builder (Develop > Show Extension Builder)
    4. Add your new extension from: $SELENIUM_CHECKOUT_LOCATION/build/javascript/safari-driver/SafariDriver.safariextension
Using Safari with Watir-WebDriver It's exactly the same as any other browser: [sourcecode language="ruby"] require 'watir-webdriver' b = Watir::Browser.new :safari [/sourcecode] Caveat Emptor
  • browser.execute_script is a little flaky
  • Can't use local html files as extensions don't load
  • Can't perform browser file uploads at present
  • Not sure how to configure browser options programatically like user agent strings
Enjoy!
